docs.lead_paragraph: When my twin sons were born 34 years ago, the goal of every woman I knew, myself included, was a vaginal delivery. Alas, for me, that was not to be: the babies were just too big to make it through my narrow pelvis, and after a nightlong labor they had to be delivered surgically by Caesarean section.

headline.main: With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explores growing trend of women having elective Caesarean deliveries rather than vaginal births; describes common reasons why mother might choose Caesarean, including convenience, safety and comfort of baby and mother; holds that many common concerns about vaginal deliveries are not supported by research data; Dr W Benson Harer of American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists holds that deciding factor between Caesarean and vaginal births should be mother's preference; graph (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Penlike devices that hold injectable epinephrine for treating severe allergic reactions can be found in thousands of homes, schools and public buildings. But a new English study suggests that many people who will need the devices -- and many doctors who prescribe them -- are woefully ill-informed about how they work. The study was conducted by members of an allergy clinic in Surrey who noticed that many patients or parents referred to the clinic seemed to know little about the injectable epinephrine, a hormone produced by the adrenal gland that can often reverse asthma attacks or allergic reactions.

headline.main: Learning How to Save a Life

docs.abstract: Surrey (England) allergy clinic conducts study on general knowledge and use of injectable epinephrine to stop severe allergy and asthma attacks; finds many doctors and patients do not know when or how to give injections (S)
docs.snippet: Penlike devices that hold injectable epinephrine for treating severe allergic reactions can be found in thousands of homes, schools and public buildings. But a new English study suggests that many people who will need the devices -- and many doctors...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pain gets most of the attention when it comes to arthritis of the knee. But a new study that tracked a group of older patients for three years found that factors like self-confidence and social support also appeared to predict who was able to avoid being disabled by the arthritis. Researchers from the Northwestern University medical school administered a variety of physical tests to 236 patients in their mid- to late 60's, and had them fill out questionnaires. In three years, the researchers identified a number of factors associated with declining knee function, including severity of pain and looseness in the joint.
docs.abstract: Dr Leena Sharma, Northwestern University medical school researcher, leads study published in journal Arthritis and Rheumatology that finds good mental health and social support positively impact health of those individuals suffering from arthritis; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Pain gets most of the attention when it comes to arthritis of the knee. But a new study that tracked a group of older patients for three years found that factors like self-confidence and social support also appeared to predict who was able to avoid...

docs.lead_paragraph: A modest amount of leg-strengthening jumping exercises added to gym classes for girls on the brink of puberty resulted in significant gains in bone mass and strength, a Canadian study published yesterday found. Brittle bones are a major health concern for older women, but the bulk of bone strength is laid down in younger years, and early adolescence is a particularly critical time, according to the study, published in the journal Pediatrics.
docs.abstract: Dr Heather McKay, University of British Columbia researcher, leads study on bone strength and jumping exercises for young girls; study, published in journal Pediatrics, shows that moderate amounts of jumping increases bone mass by average of 5 percent in elementary school-age girls; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A modest amount of leg-strengthening jumping exercises added to gym classes for girls on the brink of puberty resulted in significant gains in bone mass and strength, a Canadian study published yesterday found.    Brittle bones are a major health...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who get more upset by disturbing events are more likely to suffer the declines in memory and mental ability found in Alzheimer's disease, according to a study published today. The study tracked a group of priests, nuns and monks as part of a long-term examination of the aging process.

headline.main: In Aging, Distress Takes Its Toll

docs.abstract: Dr Robert S Wilson, Chicago's Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center researcher, leads study on effects of mental distress or neuroticism on development of Alzheimers; study looked at 800 members of Religious Orders Study and found those men and women who scored highest on neuroticism test were twice as likely over next five years to develop Alzheimer's; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who get more upset by disturbing events are more likely to suffer the declines in memory and mental ability found in Alzheimer's disease, according to a study published today.     The study tracked a group of priests, nuns and monks as part of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Magno-Humphries of Tigard, Ore., had voluntarily recalled a group of 504 bottles of Dixon's APAP acetaminophen 325-milligram analgesic tablets. The acetaminophen is an over-the-counter product sold in 100-tablet bottles.

headline.main: Acetaminophen Tablets Recalled Over Mislabeling on Size of Dose

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration reports that Magno-Humphries, pharmaceutical company, has voluntarily recalled 504 bottles of Dixon's APAP acetaminophen tablets because bottles contain 500-milligram tablets instead of 325 milligrams per tablet reflected on label (S)
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Magno-Humphries of Tigard, Ore., had voluntarily recalled a group of 504 bottles of Dixon's APAP acetaminophen 325-milligram analgesic tablets.     The acetaminophen is an over-the-counter product...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Overcoming Dyslexia,'' by Dr. Sally Shaywitz. Knopf, $25.95. Early in this book about a disorder that may afflict one child in every five in America, the author dispels two widely held beliefs: that children with dyslexia are prone to seeing letters or words backward, and that the problem is linked to intelligence.
docs.abstract: Book Overcoming Dyslexia by Dr Sally e Shaywitz, Yale University pediatrics professor, explores myths about disorder, which is believed to effect one in every five children in United States, and offers suggestions about overcoming reading difficulties; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Susan Kilgore smokes outside now. It has nothing to do with Dallas's no-smoking laws. She is trying to save her nine cats' lives.

headline.main: Secondhand Smoke May Harm Family Pets, Too

docs.abstract: Dr John S Reif, Colorado State University environmental health professor, leads study that finds pet owners who smoke are likely creating hazardous secondhand smoke environment for their pets; study, published in American Journal of Epidemiology, supports other research into pet health that shows increased risk of cancer in both dogs and cats living in smoker's homes; retired veterinarian Dr Hugh B Norris holds that pet owners confronted with issue of secondhand smoke do not want to believe ailment of pets is related to smoking or are unable to quit; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Susan Kilgore smokes outside now.    It has nothing to do with Dallas's no-smoking laws. She is trying to save her nine cats' lives.

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.; Carole Corm contributed reporting from Paris for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: With a major malaria outbreak sweeping Ethiopia, an international doctors' group working there contends that outdated drugs are being used to fight it and may even worsen the epidemic. Unicef, the United Nations agency providing the drugs, defended the choices it made in consultation with the Ethiopian government. The older drugs are still effective, it said, and changing policy midepidemic for a health system as battered as Ethiopia's can be disastrous.

headline.main: In Ethiopia's Malaria War, Weapons Are the Issue

docs.abstract: Malaria kills three children per minute worldwide and recent economic hardships in Ethiopia combined with infection have translated into worst malaria epidemic since 1998; Doctors Without Borders, advocacy group, argues that older drugs being used by Unicef in conjunction with Ethiopian government not only fail to combat current strain, but create even larger problem through stimulation of gametocyte cells, which group holds speed spread of Malaria; use of artemisinin cocktails discussed; World Health Organization holds that Ethiopia's epidemic is expected to spread to estimated 15 million of 65 million citizens; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With a major malaria outbreak sweeping Ethiopia, an international doctors' group working there contends that outdated drugs are being used to fight it and may even worsen the epidemic.    Unicef, the United Nations agency providing the drugs,...

docs.lead_paragraph: As the health officer of Alameda County, Dr. Anthony Iton is prepared to make tough choices if SARS re-emerges this winter or spring, as many infectious disease experts fear. The county, just across the bay from here, has identified two large buildings where, if voluntary steps to quell an epidemic were to fail, the authorities could sequester not just people who were sick but also people who might have been exposed to the SARS virus, Dr. Iton said.

headline.main: If SARS Hits U.S., Quarantine Could Too

docs.abstract: Alameda County (Calif) health officer Dr Anthony Iton holds that SARS or another highly infectious disease will likely effect US in coming years; contends preparation for outbreak is key to controlling it; is implementing components of draft SARS plan released in fall 2003 by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and has identified areas to be used as quarantine centers if necessary; delicate balance between effective outbreak management and respect for individual's civil liberties debated; Barry Steinhardt of American Civil Liberties Union's Program of Technology and Liberty expresses doubts that Americans will easily accept quarantine regulations or other possible infringements on life style; photo (S)
